title: 113_hr2633
content:
The Act is titled the "Thirteenth Amendment Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The economic contributions of enslaved African Americans to the American economy between 1691 and 1860 were immeasurable, building the foundations of America. Colonial economies in the Americas were dependent on enslaved African labor, including the North American mercantile and shipping sectors. Enslaved Africans were also crucial in the political and economic capital of the United States. During 246 years, enslaved Africans provided 605 billion hours of forced labor, fueling the American economy, financing key sectors, and aiding in funding both world wars. President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation during the Civil War added a new dimension to the nation's war aims. The Civil War evolved from a conflict to preserve the Union to a crusade to end slavery and uphold the Declaration of Independence. In 1864, the 13th Amendment, prohibiting slavery and granting Congress enforcement power, was passed by the Senate after debates on the moral issue of slavery. The 13th Amendment was promoted by President Lincoln to end slavery, with members of the Republican Party like Charles Sumner rejecting slavery as incompatible with moral law. Lincoln ensured the party's 1864 platform included support for the amendment, which ultimately succeeded in Congress. Illinois was the first state to ratify the proposed 13th Amendment on February 1, 1865, followed by 17 other states by the end of the month. Georgia became the 27th state to approve the Amendment on December 6, 1865. The 13th Amendment was declared part of the Constitution by Secretary of State William Seward on December 18. The Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture was established by an Act of Congress in 2003. The NMAAHC would receive surcharges from the sale of coins issued under Public Law 108-184 to raise funding for its endowment and educational outreach programs. The NMAAHC would receive surcharges from the sale of coins issued under Public Law 108-184 to raise funding for its endowment and educational outreach programs. Coin specifications are outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue commemorative coins for the Sesquicentennial Anniversary of the 13th Amendment, including $50 bi-metallic platinum and gold coins, $20 gold coins, and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and gold/silver content limits. The coins minted under this Act for the Sesquicentennial Anniversary of the 13th Amendment will have a diameter of 40.6 millimeters and contain .999 fine silver. They shall be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins for the Sesquicentennial Anniversary of the 13th Amendment will have a diameter of 40.6 millimeters and contain .999 fine silver, being legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will symbolize the Thirteenth Amendment and the end of slavery in America. They will feature inscriptions of the year "1865-2015", along with words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will highlight the economic contributions of slavery and depict the journey from slavery to freedom. The $20 coins may have design elements in high relief, while the $50 coins could include an illustration of Columbia on the obverse. The design of the coins will feature an illustration of Columbia or a similar figure representing Liberty on the obverse, and a single eagle with stars on the reverse. The selection will be made by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities in 2016. The Secretary can start sales before January 1, 2016, and continue minting coins in that year. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

Coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount as well. The Act requires a $10 surcharge per coin sold, with all surcharges going to the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture. The museum is audited for the funds received. No surcharge exceptions are allowed. No surcharge can be added to any coin issued under this Act if it would exceed the annual limit of 2 commemorative coin programs. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide guidance on this limitation. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure that minting and issuing coins under this Act will not cost the US Government. No funds will be disbursed until the total cost of designing and issuing all authorized coins is recovered by the US Treasury.
